title: Will legislation amending or repealing Section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934 become law before 14 August 2021?
preds: While drafted, it has not been formally introduced yet by House Republicans.  https://www.foxbusiness.com/politics/house-republicans-draft-bill-to-strip-big-tech-companies-of-section-230-protections If it is a robust overhaul, it will certainly sit in committee for a while for review before being out out to vote in the House and then the Senate. With 4 days until the deadline, that is not going to happen quickly.
It's always possible that some obscure thing could come through that amends 230. Other than that, nothing on the radar in Congress right now that I can tell.

Former President Trump's lawsuits against Facebook, Twitter and Google have again shined a spotlight on Section 230, but the majority of legal experts agree there is no basis within his lawsuit to change the statute.  Congress may eventually take notice, but there are other things like COVID, New Green Deal and the rest of the infrastructure plan to worry about right now.  This will likely not happen in this session of Congress.
https://www.zdnet.com/article/trump-takes-aim-at-section-230-with-lawsuit-against-facebook-twitter-and-google/

Everybody agrees that Section 230 needs work.  Nobody has agreed to work on it, though, as this would require the Sharks to speak civilly  to the Jets, or the Montagues to the Capulets, or some equally distasteful exercise.
I've seen absolutely no movement on this.

Lowering probability again for passage of time.  Not much going on in Congress, but there are a host of other challenges to Section 230 that will become important over time (if challenged in a higher court).
https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/some-interesting-cda-section-230-8391611/
-4% We're seeing no progress in Congress on this, and with such a short window I don't see it happening.
time elapsed with no bipartisan progress

Going to zero given the passage of time and the lack of major legislation introduced or being discussed.  The budget and infrastructure will take all the oxygen between now and August recess, in my view.

Doubled base rate and accounted for passage of time. "No news is bad news." Why double? Because of the high profile nature. But aren't many proposed legislation part of the base rate high profile? Yes but what gives? Why not go higher? Because there does not seem to have any plans or momentum.
-5 as I've seen no news on legislation related to this recently.

Revoking of an executive order by a former U.S. president that amended  Section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934 (Section 9 of the Communications Decency Act / Section 509 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996). "President Biden on Friday revoked former President Trump’s executive order from May 2020 targeting online censorship. Trump wanted interactive computer services such as  Twitter, Facebook, and Google, among others, to be held responsible for content posted to their platforms. In Trump’s Executive Order 13925 of May 28, 2020, he wrote that the policy of the United States should be that “an internet provider be exposed to liability like any traditional editor and publisher that is not an online provider.” Trump specifically addressed Section 230 of the U.S. Code,[...]"
https://www.dailywire.com/news/biden-revokes-trumps-order-targeting-online-censorship
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communications_Decency_Act
Too many other priorities, for any action on this right now, I think.
Too many other fish to fry, no bandwidth or huge motivation to focus on this.

Down to zero. FB continues the Trump ban for 6 more months as they attempt to figure out what their rules should be.  Congress has no urgent need to address this in the next few months. Not a priority for Democrats or the Biden presidency as far as I can tell.

There has been zero movement from Democrats or Republicans on this.  I'm not sure they'll reform anything until they can agree to the "why" first.
Everyone: https://www.brookings.edu/techstream/a-guide-for-conceptualizing-the-debate-over-section-230/
Republicans: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/15/house-republicans-outline-principles-for-reforming-section-230.html
Supreme Court: https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/factcheck/2021/04/08/fact-check-post-misrepresents-justice-thomas-section-230/7122886002/
If there were more grownups left in the Congress, this would have happened by now.

Lots of bipartisan support for reforming Section 230, including from the tech companies themselves.  Yet, no one can seem to agree on how to go about doing it, or what it should be replaced with.  Not feeling good about a 14 August deadline.

Lots of recommendations for section 230 change, but I haven't seen anything yet that has enough bipartisan support to get through the congressional process and become law by Aug of this year. decent summary of some of the proposed section 230 reforms on both sides and bipartisan.
https://digiday.com/media/section-230-reforms/ one take on an area for bipartisan cooperation, recommends supporting "notice and take down" of content as an area for bipartisan cooperation and tabling all the other issues to be dealt with in later (and possibly independent of section 230) legislation. I'm not convinced the democrats and republicans can agree on a standard of what content should be subject to "notice and take down" so I'm unconvinced this is a viable bipartisan recommendation.
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/techtank/2021/03/17/back-to-the-future-for-section-230-reform/?utm_campaign=Center%20for%20Technology%20Innovation&utm_medium=email&utm_content=117420087&utm_source=hs_email

Dropping my forecast 15 to 10%. Seems increasingly unlikely that Section 230 will be amended / repealed before September 2021. I could see some laws coming into place surrounding the topic of tech and their role in content moderation but I do not see anything that suggests an overhaul to 230 in the cards this year.

One set of bipartisan reforms for Section 230 outlined in the Fox News article: the "PACT Act," would preserve the benefits of Section 230 while making "significant reforms" to protect Americans using the platforms (not very specific, but would give consumers more understanding of the algorithms for the information they are seeing, while at the same time providing an appeals process if a site took down some information, to include when not providing a reason for removing it).  At the same time, the New York Times argues that there is still too much contention over what Section 230 means, what will replace it, and (again) what the second and third order effects would be.  This legislation will be changed.  Now I'm stuck on "when". https://www.foxnews.com/politics/schatz-thune-bipartisan-plan-section-230-reforms-big-tech-accountability
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/09/technology/section-230-congress.html

Appears to be less imminent at the moment, even though it is of great importance in order to adapt to explosive developments of the past two decades and given the importance that internet giants have in the "platform economy and society".
Revising up slightly, now that I get a sense of just how many bills there are from both sides of the aisle wanting s.230 changed, however I still don't think it will happen before August.

Revising way down due to some additional inside/outside view calculations.  Granted, the House and Senate are both democratic right now, but I'm not sure that would make a difference in how quickly Section 230 would get changed.  So, the ultimate question is, will Section 230 be amended or repealed before Congress goes into summer recess?  According to Congress.gov, it takes an average of 256 days to pass a bill into law.  The minimum has been 1 day (passage of the budget) and the maximum for a single session in recent history has been 712 days.  Not giving me hope.
At this point, not on the radar. The Senate has the COVID relief bill and still has several more Biden cabinet officials to get through

Become law before August? Please. Congress moves like molasses. Lindsey Graham's current bill is stuck in a committee chaired by Democrats, and all other bills of this same type will need to be introduced there too: https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/5020/text

several other people have posted links to the various change proposals floating around congress, the fact that there are several and that they advocate for very different things seems to indicate to me that its less likely that one will get passed into law by August.  However, California today did move forward on its own net neutrality law https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/californias-net-neutrality-law-can-go-forward-judge-rules-rcna307 The FCC believes it has the authority to "interpret ambiguous terms in Section 230(c), which contains the immunity shield. Engaging in such interpretation would not involve creating “net neutrality” rules for social media companies, much less (as some critics have claimed) a “Fairness Doctrine” for the Internet. Rather, it would involve clarifying a legal standard that already exists: the statutory immunity shield in Section 230. " https://www.fcc.gov/news-events/blog/2020/10/21/fccs-authority-interpret-section-230-communications-act So maybe there will be impetus for congress to act in order to avoid a bunch of different state laws. I'm still not convinced it is likely before 14 August though.

Lowering to less than 50%.
Democratic Senators are showing willingness to slow, amend, and change pending legislation. While there are multiple bills drafted, the reduced pressure to address social media behavior along with more deliberate lawmaking.

Too many other issues on the table. The conversation related to tech powers has moved in the direction of "yes" to the above question, but I am very doubtful any big legislation will be reached before the summer, especially under a Democratic Congress who feel less "oppressed" by the tech platforms in terms of speech rights.

With 34 proposals in play, there seems to be a lot of interest in revising this law. However, Republicans and Democrats seem to have significantly different ideas of how to change the law. I can see Republicans being willing to use the filibuster on this, so I find it unlikely that they will pass a bill by August.

Some new updates in the last couple of days (likely posted below as well).  New Dem proposed law submitted, called the SAFE TECH Act. It may be a matter of getting other legislators on board based on 2nd and 3rd order effects.
https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2021/02/15/sect-f15.html
https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2021/02/proposed-sec-230-rewrite-could-have-wide-ranging-consequences/

According to a report in the Wall Street Journal on Saturday, there are 34 different legislative proposals to update Section 230 from Democrats and Republicans in the House of Representatives, the Senate and the White House. The Journal —which describes Section 230 as the “foundational covenant between the government and internet platform”—makes the point that “the question of how to fix the internet with updates to Section 230 is far-reaching and complex.”

The number of draft actions is growing and with Democratic control of both Houses of Congress and the White House the chance of some type of signed bill is increasing. https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-congress-might-upend-section-230-the-internet-law-big-tech-is-built-on-11613172368?mod=hp_lead_pos10

SAFE TECH Act introduced by three D Senators on 05 February 2021.
https://www.warner.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/4/f/4fa9c9ba-2b34-4854-8c19-59a0a9676a31/66DECFBC0D6E6958C2520C3A6A69EAF6.safe-tech-act---final.pdf
https://mashable.com/article/section-230-safe-tech-act-reform/ Opinion by Rep. Mark Baisley
https://coloradosun.com/2021/02/07/big-tech-section-230-opinion/
Missed the news about the D amendment, still think that this won't make it through by August.
Congress has more important things to deal with this year.
With single party control and a formal draft, I am going above 50%.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/02/05/senate-warner-section-230-reform/

Bringing in an interesting perspective from the latest in the GameStop saga.  There is a lot of backlash with/about/through Reddit right now--not known as a prolific social media platform until 7 million people ended up in the s/Wallstreet Bets group. These people moved a lot of money around in a short amount of time and introduced a significant amount of instability in the market. Depending on how threatening that is to Congress, we may see more movement on this.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-04/gamestop-mania-stirs-new-ire-for-social-media-shield-trump-hates

Reducing due to press coverage on first amendment restriction markedly dropping however some elected officials are still pursuing action.
https://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article248952689.html Parler remains offline. 
Facebook's actions remain prominent in the news cycle and with seemingly true independent action being exercised by their Oversight Board, pressure will be taken off politician's to regulate the company.
https://www.cbsnews.com/news/facebook-oversight-board-first-decisions/
https://www.forbes.com/sites/rachelsandler/2021/01/29/facebooks-oversight-board-is-taking-public-comments-on-trumps-ban/?sh=50c411d5ddc0 Staying above the crowd as Twitter remains very active suspended accounts.
https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/companies/twitter-has-permanently-banned-the-corporate-mypillow-account-after-founder-mike-lindell-posted-from-it/ar-BB1djZtV

"But investors should know the Trump-era antitrust concerns that put a damper on Alphabet — as well as Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN) and Apple (AAPL) — haven't exactly gone away.
[...]
Some worry regulatory woes could plague Alphabet and the other big tech stocks even more now that Democrats have control of the House and Senate. Top lawmakers like Democratic senators Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar and independent Bernie Sanders have all expressed a desire to break up many of these companies."
https://edition.cnn.com/2021/02/01/investing/google-alphabet-stock-earnings-preview/index.html

https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/26/22250746/biden-gina-raimondo-commerce-secretary-section-230
-"Responding to questions posed by Sen. Ron Johnson (R-WI), Raimondo said that she would use the tools available through the Commerce Department’s National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) to convene stakeholders, industry leaders, lawmakers and others to identify the means of reform to the pivotal internet law." Feels like the Biden administration may make some moves without legislation, current events in the Senate are making me less and less sure 61 senators will agree on how to remake 230.   Thus I am halving my estimate.

Staying above the crowd, but I won't rise from here absent some nascent "activity" on the legislation front. (Seen enough editorials and opinions already!!) "Legislation becoming Law" must occur for a win. Question closes 6.5 months.  I believe the *effective date* is the only true "bet" we're making here. Any Experts with thots? Cheers, Gang :-)

both reps and dems want to change section 230 but for opposite reasons. dems want to pressure social media to delete more "hatespeech" and "misinformation" while reps want to pressure them to not delete stuff that is not against the law. i do not see how there can be a legislative compromise. the compromise is doing nothing.

Congressional Democrats will want to focus on bigger issues while they control both chambers and the White House. Section 230 of the Communications Act will likely be amended or repealed eventually but I do not think it will happen within the timeframe of this question. Despite the issues that both Democrats and Republicans have with Big Tech, Section 230 is probably not something that will taken up in the near future.

Both political parties see a problem, but the issue is going to be what the solution is to solve it.  New Commerce Department secretary nominee (Gina Raimondo, D-R.I.) is in favor of changes to hold internet companies accountable due to the spread of misinformation.  The leading Republican FCC commissioner (Nathan Simington) also wants to see change, mostly to uphold the previous administration's attempts to rollback liability protection.  The repeal/amendment of 230 is getting pushback from both sides as well, but I feel like the voices for the status quo are getting drowned out by those advocating for change.
https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/26/22250746/biden-gina-raimondo-commerce-secretary-section-230
https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/27/22251093/section-230-civil-rights-groups-letter-biden-harris-congress-defense

I am lowering my forecast probability, in light of the Democrat's hesitancy to abolish the filibuster, Majority Leader Schumer's continuing deference to Joe Manchin and Kyrsten Sinema, and Joe Manchin's emphatic opposition to abolishing the filibuster.[1]  The likelihood that any legislation would pass the senate by mid-August 2021 lowers considerably with the need to have 60 votes to change something as important as Section 230.  With all the money that the tech giants spend on lobbying, they will surely be able to find one senator to filibuster any proposed change until the summer recess. [1] https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/25/joe-manchin-filibuster-462364
Increasing probability somewhat, as this has some bi-partisan support. Unclear about timetabling or practicalities of getting it through at the moment

It feels equally weighted on both sides, but because resolution asks for it to become law, which I believe only 4% of laws make it through Congress, this will be hard to pass. Then again some of the analysis I have read shows decent support in Congress (big question mark?) It is especially relevant in today's times, so it is an opportunity for government to gain traction.

Facebook's READY. Lots of back and forth to still happen.. The question is WHEN will the sausage factory do its deed and any changes "Become Law". That's what we're betting.  https://about.fb.com/regulations/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=quartz&utm_campaign=USPublicAffairs&utm_content=actionregulation

Both Democrats and Republicans are in favor of some sort of change (amendment or repeal) of Section 230.  So it's really not "if" but "when".  For a baseline, the last study I could find on when and why laws are repealed in the United States was from 2015, for a data set of legislature from 1877-2012.  The thesis of this research was: There are increases in repealing activity when (1) the majority party is ideologically unified and (2) the majority came into power after a long stint in the minority. The first statement applies, as Democrats now control the executive, house, and senate.  But the legislation was in place for long enough that either party could have repealed or amended it in some way after re-taking control of any branch of government.  Both parties want it changed (though maybe not for the same reasons), increasing the probability that it happens.  The question that must be asked based on this research is: Is Section 230 at the same priority level for amendment or repeal as the Affordable Care Act or some other tax law has been in the past. President Biden's new Federal Trade Commission chair said this week she believes "Section 230 is an 'important area to consider reform,' so long as the law wasn't changed to require social media companies to be viewpoint neutral and unbiased in their content moderation." https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/usappblog/2015/10/16/understanding-when-and-why-congress-repeals-laws-is-as-important-as-looking-at-how-it-makes-them/
https://www.legbranch.org/2015-10-19-when-does-congress-repeal-legislation-a-new-dataset-of-major-repeals-from-1877-2012-provides-answers/
https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/biden-selects-acting-federal-trade-commission-chairwoman

President Biden has called for a repeal of 230 and both sides of the aisle are frustrated with "Big Tech." Democrats are frustrated with too little moderation and Republicans are perturbed with too much; however, both parties focus on confronting internet speech is increased thanks to the Capitol Hill riots.
https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2021/01/20/biden-trump-censorship-section-230-google-facebook-scrutiny/4238357001/

I think @Okanaganopolis is right, it's just a question of when this will happen.  The crowd is at 10%, which sounds about right.  Both the Congress and the Administration have a lot on their plates, so it might not be a priority this year.  I'll throw my hat into the ring with a 13% chance.

Bipartisan howling over 230 is rising, fast. Whether the howling is the same subset of the act, I'm less certain.  But I now see this as a matter of "when" (not "If")  *the conditions of the question are met.* Climbing above the crowd and expanding study as to where/what "front" will set the stage. Question closes 180 days from today. Hmmm is that fast or slow to "amend or repeal" something?  Discuss. (Thx!)

"Twitter and the Other Platforms Are Bad, Facebook Is Worse"
Star economist Nouriel Roubini believes that President-elect Joseph Biden's first term will be overshadowed by civil unrest at home and cyberattacks from abroad. He believes social media platforms must be more strictly regulated."
https://www.spiegel.de/international/business/economist-nouriel-roubini-twitter-and-the-other-platforms-are-bad-facebook-is-worse-a-fc660029-71a4-4575-87ba-40d5bf2ab711

For this forecast, I will be directly comparing to the 2007-09 US Congress due to what I believe are its deep similarities to the 2021-23 US Congress. Namely ->
1. Democrats control both the Presidency and Congress
2. They will govern during a deep crisis point in U.S History (2008 Financial Crash / Covid 19 Pandemic) In the 2007-09 US Congress, 460 Bills became enacted of the 10,506 Bills introduced ->
https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/browse?congress=110&status=28,29,32,33 I assume this includes any amendments or repealing of existing legislation like Section 230. Of these 460 over this two year period from 2007-09, only 64% were considered "substantive" ->
https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/01/25/a-productivity-scorecard-for-115th-congress/ I believe that amending or repealing Section 230 is substantive ->
3% = 2.8% = (460 / 10,506) * 0.64 Furthermore, with this over a two year period and are asked if happens before August ->  
X1 = 1% = (8 / 24) * 3% In addition, since being introduced in 1996, its my understanding that Section 230 has been amended only once (2018) ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_230 X2 = 4% = 1 / (2020 - 1996 + 1) While there has been an increasing focus on Section 230 and the prominence of online platforms, nevertheless given the huge challenges the Biden Administration (Covid, Recession, Iran, China, Climate Change etc) will face in 2021 combined with it only having a majority of one in the Senate ->
X3 = 10% X = 5% = (X1 + X2  +X3) / 3
This will probably happen in the next year or two, but there's too much on the collective plate to deal with this so soon.

Base rate
In its 24 years of existence it has only been amended 1 time - 4% chance
In the past 4 presidencies, the time between inauguration and August 1st, an average of 23.75% of laws enacted are amendments or repeals of existing laws
(Clinton 5/28, Bush 1/11, Obama 4/24, Trump 10/20) 
https://www.congress.gov/search?pageSort=latestAction:asc&q={%22source%22:%22legislation%22,%22type%22:%22bills%22,%22bill-status%22:%22law%22,%22congress%22:[%22107%22]}&searchResultViewType=expanded I combine those two factors for my base rate of 13.88%.  Options for change include: 1. A full repeal, 2. Amending platform’s ability to moderate themselves, 3. Amend the liability shield for platforms, 4. Amend a small, insignificant technical detail for the political win of standing up to big tech. 1. Full repeal - Minute possibility (increases chances 1%)
“The complete repeal of Section 230 that Trump screamed for on his now-banned Twitter account isn’t likely — that would upend the entire internet — but the kind of reform many Democrats called for is very possible.”
https://www.vox.com/recode/22221135/capitol-riot-section-230-twitter-hawley-democrats
Although Biden called for a “full repeal” on the campaign trail, that quote was in reference to Facebook abusing its power, and appears to have been made without understanding the full context of the repercussions. Repercussion — ie “upending the entire internet —  which would create wide anger toward the Democratic party and would be in conflict with the Democrats’ focus on the 2022 midterm (See Democratic priority section at the end). 2. Amend platforms’ ability to moderate themselves - Minute possibility (increases chances 1%)
This has been the focus of Republicans who are angry at what they see as the suppression of conservative voices by social media. The election of Biden and flipping of the Senate all but kill the likelihood of this being the focus of a Section 230 amendment. However, the democrats may reach for republican support, seeing as Section 230 has become a stand-in for “big tech has too much power”. That being said, the “conservative voices” the Republicans are upset at being silenced, are often the same voices the Democrats are made at for spreading “hate speech”. Cracking down on hate speech is a focus of Democratic amendments, thus cooperation seems unlikely. Additionally, as seen in the Obama years, recent attempts at bipartisanship have consistently been shut down by Republican leadership. 3. Amend the liability shield for platforms - possible path (increases chances 10%)
- There is already a framework for this kind of change in the form of 2018 FOSTA, which removed liability coverage in cases of sex trafficking
- The EARN IT Act (2020) followed the FOSTA framework, focusing on Child pornography as opposed to sex trafficking. However, tech companies and free speech activists have called the act a “trojan horse” to control wider-ranging speech and encryption.  https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2020/03/proposed-us-law-is-trojan-horse-to-stop-online-encryption-critics-say/
- The Protecting Americans from Dangerous Algorithms Act. This would remove immunity if algorithms continue to push individuals toward extremist content, users, or groups. 
- Recent events at the US capitol make this kind of a change far more politically relevant, and the fact that it will not upend the internet makes it less of a poison pill for the 2022 elections. (See Democratic strategy section for why this does not increase chances more) 4. Amend a small, insignificant technical detail for the political win of standing up to big tech (increases likelihood by 1%)
- This would be a short term victory only, once the next big story of a big tech abuse or a hate crime organized on social media breaks democrats would be blasted for ineffective governing. If a change were to be made, Democrats will want to be able to show how it made a difference. 5. Will this be enough of a Democratic priority to warrant a spot in Bidens first 7 months?
-Very unlikely (subtracts 6% chance) 
-As seen above new presidents’ first 7 months average 20 meaningful bills passed into law (I excluded bills naming a building, extending funding, and recognizing individuals).
- “Biden’s speech last night, laying out a $1.9 trillion economic plan, made that clear. His agenda will remain more tightly linked to the immediate crisis than Obama’s. Although Obama also began his presidency with a huge stimulus bill, he soon pivoted to health care and climate change, which had only tenuous connections to the housing meltdown that led to the recession. Biden shows no sign of pivoting to anything so removed from the coronavirus.”
- “He is already planning a second piece of legislation that will include spending on clean-energy and infrastructure programs to put people back to work and tax increases on the wealthy to reduce the deficit.”
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/15/briefing/biden-stimulus-indonesia-earthquake-impeachment-vote.html
- Recent rhetoric suggests Biden will base his strategy on achieving wins that are focused on the current problems of the American people and thus are focused on relief and recovery from the Covid pandemic and economic crisis 
- I accept that individual members of congress could organize an amendment to the law, and Biden has clearly signaled that he is interested in an amendment. But the political capital necessary to overcome big tech’s expected lobbying and the fear of such an amendment upending the internet — subsequently turning off voters — strikes me as obstacles that will not be overcome without a plan from the top of the Democratic Party

Despite Biden proposing revoking this law and generally not being a fan of it, I project that the Biden Administration and US Congressional delegates will prioritize other domestic agendas ahead of this item, largely in part to the COVID-19 recovery. https://www.theverge.com/21273768/section-230-explained-internet-speech-law-definition-guide-free-moderation
I don't see this happening in a Democrat-led congress.

After last week's chaos at the Capitol and the resulting fallout on social media, if repeal doesn't happen, there are likely to be some changes.  Both parties have stated that they've wanted changes made, both to the tech companies' moderation policies as well as consequences for users. Joe Biden said he would like to repeal Section 230 (stated in Jan 2020). The problem is, this doesn't just affect social media, but ALL user-generated content on the internet, including (linked article) companies like AirBnB.  So, in addition to Facebook, Twitter, Google, and Parler, I am now almost seeing this as something akin to antitrust. Amended or repealed, it may end up at the Supreme Court.
https://www.barrons.com/articles/repealing-section-230-portion-of-internet-law-would-be-terrible-for-airbnb-heres-why-51610409540

Democratic controlled congress will be less likely to oppose big tech in ways that GOP does.  Big tech will be more weary of democratic controlled government and act in ways for more favorable regulation.
The fact that the CEO of Google was/is a personal counselor to Biden is enough power to crush any attempt!

TLDR: Biden administration will likely leave this issue up to congress, don't expect more executive orders on the topic to galvanize action so we're most likely entirely on congress's timeline for this issue. However, the issue has gotten a priority bump in congress after the insurrection, and twitter's permanent ban  may have paradoxically driven the left and right closer together on the issue of regulating companies under section 230.
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/techtank/2020/12/03/what-to-expect-from-a-biden-fcc-on-section-230-net-neutrality-and-5g/
https://www.newsweek.com/aclu-counsel-warns-unchecked-power-twitter-facebook-after-trump-suspension-1560248

This change is complex and not clear that it addresses the issues raised regarding tech platforms in the last few months, including the attack on the US Capitol last week.  Have not hear clear message from leading Democrats since result in US Senate elections last week.  Given Aug 2021 deadline starting with 5% until clearer picture emerges regarding priorities of new Congress and incoming Administration.

Because Democrats now control both the House and the Senate, this is unlikely a priority.  In fact, I'd think they would avoid getting sucked into this issue as it has a Republican frame around it.  But they aren't always smart about these traps either so I give it 5%.

This is a hot-button issue that will shift rapidly.  The current push from conservative voices against 'big tech' companies along with the fallout of the banning of President Trump and Parler will keep this in the public eye.  However, since repeal of section 230 is likely to lead to *greater* requirements on tech companies to moderate inaccurate and misleading content, it seems likely to me that the Democrats will avoid taking this issue up out of political fear of appearing to crack down even further on conservative discourse (which this action would cause).

The recently enacted ban on President Trump to use Twitter will bring this to a head.  The challenge will be that the ban will be seen as stifling Conservative Voices.  With the subsequent elimination of Parler from both Apple and Google platforms, the attack has escalated to a point where the Conservative Minority must push a reckoning.  There will be a modification to the Statute sometime this year.  August is a reasonable date depending on what happens between now and then.

Given the Biden administration’s priority on COVID relief and vaccination, jobs, healthcare, and climate change to “build back better,” it seems unlikely that major legislation regarding Section 230 will make it through in the first eight months of Biden presidency.  It would seem odd to devote so much early energy and time to something that is so far outside of the everyday concerns of working Americans, which Biden says he is focused on.  When you throw in the possibility of losing February to another impeachment, it doesn’t seem likely.  I do think it will eventually pass especially as we get closer to the 2022 midterm elections.  But not in the first eight months.

President-elect Biden has been critical of 230 in the past and called for its repeal in the past. Democrats have focused on the dangers of misinformation on social media platforms while republicans point that there is an anti-conservative bias in the way content is moderated and displayed. There are a few bills already drafted that have bipartisan support and could be used as a foundation for amending section 230.  The counter to this argument would be that many internet service companies have already begun moderating content on their own: 1.  On 8 Jan 2021, Twitter banned the President's personal account  
2.  Facebook and Instagram have temporarily suspended the President's account for 2 weeks Even financial services companies such as Visa and Mastercard have forced a third party vendor (Pornhub) to remove content or face restrictions.   There is a clear need for changes to Section 230 but how will these recent actions affect the lawmakers' calculus on section 230 in the timeframe allotted?  With everything else going on in the country, how important is this piece of legislation vice others (e.g. additional CoVID relief)? Source:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/no-blanket-protection-for-internet-platforms-11609779436?mod=searchresults_pos2&page=1
https://www.theverge.com/21273768/section-230-explained-internet-speech-law-definition-guide-free-moderation

With this rapidly having become a partisan issue, I am revising this back down to the base rate on amendments. In 2018 it was revised to make clear that websites that traffic in prostitution don't have protections: https://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2018/03/21/591622450/section-230-a-key-legal-shield-for-facebook-google-is-about-to-change It's always possible there's something similar out there that will cause another amendment. But GOP calls to repeal the law (which would actually INCREASE the amount of censorship these sites do)... will certainly go nowhere.
With Republican's having little power, very unlikely that anything happens in this space. Lower on the priority list for Democrats overall.
I'm afraid this is one of those questions where events are of fast accelerating nature, and will overtake my forecasting soon.

After the events at the capitol this week (Jan 6) I feel it is likely that lawmakers will go after section 230. President-elect Biden has been critical of 230 in the past and called for its repeal in Jan 2020. Democrats seem to focus on the dangers of misinformation on social media platforms while republicans point that there is an anti-conservative bias in the application of policy infringements. However, despite the different approaches, there are a few bills already drafted that have bipartisan support and could be used as a foundation for amending section 230. Therefore, given the President-elect's views on the bill, events at the capitol, and democratic control of the congress I feel an amendment or repeal could happen.  Sources I used 
https://www.theverge.com/21273768/section-230-explained-internet-speech-law-definition-guide-free-moderation
https://fortune.com/2020/12/30/section-230-repeal-trump-stimulus-checks/
https://www.protocol.com/section-230-2020
https://www.wsj.com/articles/no-blanket-protection-for-internet-platforms-11609779436?mod=searchresults_pos2&page=1
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tech-liability/democrats-prefer-scalpel-over-jackhammer-to-reform-key-u-s-internet-law-idUSKBN27E1IA
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/techtank/2020/12/03/what-to-expect-from-a-biden-fcc-on-section-230-net-neutrality-and-5g/
https://www.newsweek.com/fact-check-would-repealing-section-230-promote-free-speech-trump-says-1557886
Big Tech has banned Trump. The Democrats will reward them.
Reiterating. I think the consensus is too low. There has been change before and better regulation of tech companies is certainly on the agenda.

These two articles in my opinion highlight exactly the threshold this question will be resolved on. President Trump's popularity does not appear to be diminishing in any way. Simultaneously, more and more action seems to be expected and will be taken as President Trump on digital platforms. 
The legislative action might end up being minor and/or effectively administrative, but it would seem Congressional action will be necessary to defuse the divergence in these two trends. https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/01/07/trump-twitter-ban/ https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/01/07/congress-election-biden-capitol-live-updates/#link-KLUZRTJ26NDHLKR42JEPXUTREY

Looks like the Democrats will control the Senate which means they have the votes to pass things into law. https://www.house.gov/the-house-explained/the-legislative-process#:~:text=If%20the%20bill%20passes%20by,of%20100)
however, they probably don't have enough votes to overcome Republican opposition (filibuster)  on contentious legislation like this is bound to be. https://www.brookings.edu/policy2020/votervital/what-is-the-senate-filibuster-and-what-would-it-take-to-eliminate-it/
 It is possible that this could get added into some other bill like the budget, President Trump vetoed the last defense appropriations bill b/c he thought this issue ought to have been included--republican senators did not agree and overrode the veto this January. But I think its unlikely that this gets added to one of the budget bills in the future and even if it does I think it is even more unlikely that it would become law before 14 Aug 2021. The only reason I'm not going lower is that it's possible that the Democrats will work to eliminate the filibuster rule altogether thus enabling them to pass even contentious legislation. 
It is also possible that the Republican narrative on Section 230 changes once President Trump leaves office, especially in the wake of yesterday's violence viewed as having been incited by social media posts.  I don't think this is likely, but it is possible that something major could change between now and Aug on a topic that moves this fast.

With the recent election results, it doesn't appear likely that the incoming administration will do much to silence social media. The fact that lead members of the major technical social media companies have joined the Biden transition team is indicative of this.

The new Biden administration could look to limit what is allowed on social media citing Trump supporters and their ability to organize for events similar to what happened in DC. Though left wing groups started riots in multiple American cities this past summer using the same means, the Democrats can take advantage of their governmental control to adjust the rules in their favor.

I’m struggling with this one a bit, but I think I have to raise my probability. Tough going against the crowd on this one, but here’s my rationale:
1 I realize I miscalculated my base rate. Should be 7% instead of 12% since the question ends in August. 
2. I said in my initial forecast that if Democrats took the senate, I see a 1 in 3 probability of Section 230 being amended. After further consideration, I’m not sure if I’m all the way there. 
- their margin is razor thin
- is this worth political capital given everything else they got elected on (covid, climate, inequality, etc.)? As a result I decided to split the difference between 33% and 7% and go with 20%. I think this could still be too high, but we’ll see where we go from here.

Amending section 230 is no easy task.  When congree passes major regulation or amends existing ones it does so in a broad and sweeping manner because a small change is not worth all the deal making and vote wrangling.  To change section 230 wluld be an apocalyptic change impacting the inter user. Right or wrong it would be a political sword to  behead an incumbent.  Such a change is only possible with a ringing alarm and no alarm is ringing. Politicians have better legislative bills to wrangle over than this one. This is chris cox's testimony to senate committee in 2020considering legislation to amend 230. Useful primer. https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.commerce.senate.gov/services/files/BD6A508B-E95C-4659-8E6D-106CDE546D71&ved=2ahUKEwiL2aOK-4fuAhWSF1kFHdNuApkQFjAEegQIChAB&usg=AOvVaw2v-hZgyjj1onrIVcfxyrsh&cshid=1609960597886

Very uncertain on this one. Both parties have criticized it, so it could be a rare opportunity for bipartisanship. But the parties usually criticize it for different reasons (Democrats for it's role in allowing the spread of false or misleading news, Republicans for perceived censorship of conservatives). Biden has criticized it as well. I'm hedging my uncertainty toward the crowd a bit, but with it being hit from both sides I'm not at all confident that it gets left alone.

So I think the base rate depends on whether or not congress can take action on contentious issues, I think bipartisan action is unlikely so that depends on which party controls the senate.
And it also depends on whether the Democrats want to make this a priority which is at the moment unclear. Both Democrats and Republicans want to amend or repeal (respectively in general) this law, but they have very different ideas about how it should be changed.  It has been heavily politicized  (tied to defense appropriations bill and to stimulus check debate as a bargaining chip) so its unlikely that the two sides will come to any consensus in the near term.  If the Democrats take both senate seats (results this week probably) then they would have the ability to change this without bipartisan support.  But I'm not convinced that this issue stays at the top of the legislative agenda under the new administration.
The Biden transition team has listed, Covid, economic recovery, racial equality and climate change as its priorities https://buildbackbetter.gov/priorities/
From that point of view, Section 230 ties tangentially to economic recovery because of its impact on businesses which probably argues against changing it, and also to racial equality through its ties to policing hate speech which probably argues for changing it. Also the main reason it is in the news right now is the Trump administration's claims that it has been used to censor conservative political voices in social media, and it seems like continuing that argument serves the Republicans more than the Democrats so there might be a desire to leave this issue alone for awhile especially if the Republicans maintain control of the Senate.

Far too short a timeline for an industry that is not well understood by legislators. With other issues on the docket I don't see much hope of this going far and with a divided congress this will be worse. Even if Dems win senate over, I don't see much consensus being made in 6 months.

With the potential for amending, I can’t help but hesitate with my -0- Overturning Section 230 would essentially cause censorship of all online materials, including comments. If you can be sued for what someone responds, it is scary stuff.  So no on repeal.  There are many items facing congress, and if McConnell remains, nothing proposed by the Democrats in the House will see the light of day in the Senate.  He only added it to the stimulus because it would kill it.

Section 23 was passed in 1996 and there have been two amendments for a base rate of 12%.  Republicans and democrats both want to take actions, but for different reasons which makes bipartisanship unlikely. To me the key rests on the senate race in Georgia. I view both races as a toss-up so the odds of both flipping are 25%.  If that happens, I think the odds of legislation getting passed this year are roughly 1 in 3. It is still an uphill battle if only one democratic senator needs to object.  All in all this means there is a roughly 8% chance of Democrats winning the senate and passing legislation. If Republicans pick up at least one seat in Georgia, I think the odds fall to 6%.

Oops, missed the point about "amending" section 230. It was last amended in 2018 to add stuff about prostitution in subsection (e)(5): https://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?req=(title:47%20section:230%20edition:prelim)#amendment-note Although the base rate is about 10% (It has been amended twice: in 2018 and 1998), probably is more like 20% that *something* gets amended, since it's been in the spotlight lately.  Odds of a full repeal are like 0.1%.
McConnell tied Section 230 repeal to the $2,000 stimulus checks bill for a reason
Power of social media companies not enough
I can't see a route, regardless of the run-off results, am I missing anything?

I believe this will be one of the hottest issues of this year's legislative session.  President-elect Biden has been non-committal and has built a staff that has both strong advocates and strong opponents. It appears administration policy will take time to be formulated. This is a complicated question.  Anyway I’m not certain this is the right question to ask.
Potential for minor amendments in new administration. Small chance of last-gasp changes before Jan 20th

Don’t give too much credit to Trump’s current efforts (would probably be 5% or less if that was the limit of the Q). If it was repeal only would probably have that as my forecast, but with amendment also within the definition I think you have to be higher. I think changes in big tech regulation are likely - and while i suspect 230 will not be changed fundamentally, you can easily see a wording tweak getting in there. There was an amendment in 2018 for example.

Haven't followed this closely at all, since it was clearly not going anywhere in '20, but one gathers there are things about 230 that could stand fixing, and agreeing to some tinkering would be a lovely way to demonstrate the newfound bipartisan spirit, if such exists.  It won't be repealed,. though.   Please remember that I haven't followed this closely yet, so disregard everything I say about it for a while.
